ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 111 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 111 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: I think I would if you're really desperately trying to get a fifth class in and don't mind taking a credit d seminar once a week where discussion is rambling but if you're really interested in the material and hoping to get a lot out of it you'll be disappointed.

Fantastic. I'd say the best class in any of the humanities offered at Yale. In-depth, difficult, interesting, wide-ranged readings, well-led and open discussion, and great essay direction. Utopia/Dystopia is such a great topic that can be both incredibly specific and very general. Combines the close-reading of fiction with the analytical specificity of sociology and philosophy. A brilliant scholar who obviously knows his stuff, Dr. Berger brings a depth of reading and analytical thought to his teaching that is remarkable, well-organized, and makes for a fantastic class. He can get people to talk in class, and brings out student's ideas in class discussion. He assigns a difficult, in-depth, and eclectic mix of readings and comes to class with questions and ideas prepared, while still remaining open to students' ideas
